newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's Victoria loses shipping terminal deal.
newsitem.headline: Australia's Victoria loses shipping terminal deal.

text.p: The Victorian state government said on Friday an Asian shipping venture had withdrawn from a deal to build a container terminal at the Port of Melbourne.

Victoria's treasurer, Alan Stockdale said Victorian International Container Terminal Pty Ltd (VICT), a joint venture between Orient Overseas Container Line and China Ocean Shipping Co (COSCO) Group had withdrawn its offer after it was given a deadline of July 16 to file a final proposal.
Stockdale told a media briefing that the VICT offer represented about one quarter of the site's commercial value, and the government was not prepared to "give away" the site.

"They wanted to be given a container terminal in Melbourne in order to promote a competitive advantage for their ships over other ships coming into the port," Stockdale said in a radio news broadcast.
In a statement, VICT said it had been frustrated and embarrassed by the bureaucratic processes and insincerity of the Victorian government and the Port of Melbourne Corp.

"VICT proposed a financially viable project in line with international standards and which had the added benefit of lowering costs, delivering port reform through a ground-breaking agreement with the Maritime Union of Australia, and bringing
much needed competition to the Port of Melbourne," the company said in a statement.
VICT said the government had insisted on what is believed to be "grossly excessive and discriminatory rents" compared with rents charged to other stevedores in Melbourne.
